title: Hypertensive Emergency – Severe Headache and Visual Changes

priorities: Recognize hypertensive emergency with symptoms (end-organ risk)
keyAssessments: Neuro: LOC, weakness, speech changes, headache characteristics
Medication adherence and baseline BP if known
interventions: Notify provider urgently; continuous monitoring; obtain ECG per protocol
Reduce stimulation; safe environment; IV access + prepare ordered labs
Monitor for neuro changes/chest pain; do not advise rapid BP lowering without orders
reassessment: Frequent BP and neuro reassessment per protocol
Monitor for deterioration: confusion, weakness, chest pain, SOB
Document BP trends and symptom changes with time

sbar.S: 52F severe headache and blurry vision with BP 224/128.
sbar.B: Known HTN, stopped meds 2 weeks ago.
sbar.A: Severe hypertension with concerning symptoms—possible end-organ involvement.
sbar.R: Urgent provider review, monitoring, ECG/labs, and management orders per hypertensive emergency pathway.

checklist: Neuro: LOC, weakness, speech changes, headache characteristics
Medication adherence and baseline BP if known

options: Recognize hypertensive emergency with symptoms (end-organ risk)
Notify provider urgently; continuous monitoring; obtain ECG per protocol
Reduce stimulation; safe environment; IV access + prepare ordered labs

Apply oxygen if indicated per protocol
Prepare for ordered meds (rate control, antihypertensive drip, etc.)
Avoid advising rapid BP lowering without orders
Strict I&O if fluid issue suspected
Frequent BP and neuro reassessment per protocol
Monitor for deterioration: confusion, weakness, chest pain, SOB
Document BP trends and symptom changes with time
Assess perfusion (LOC, cap refill, urine output)
Repeat neuro check if hypertensive emergency

intake_gold.history: HTN (poor adherence) Stopped BP meds 2 weeks ago NKDA
intake_gold.findings: Severe headache 9/10; Blurry vision; Nausea; Anxious

scenario_text: A 52-year-old female presents to the emergency department complaining of severe headache and blurry vision. She reports severe headache 9/10; blurry vision; nausea; anxious. She has a history of HTN (poor adherence); current/recent medications include Stopped BP meds 2 weeks ago; allergies: NKDA. On arrival, vital signs show BP 224/128, HR 98, RR 20, temperature 36.8°C, oxygen saturation 98% RA. During assessment, she appears uncomfortable and anxious and states her symptoms are concerning.

reassessment: Reassess pain + vitals within minutes
Monitor for ECG changes, hypotension, worsening SOB

title: Congestive Heart Failure – Acute Fluid Overload
chiefComplaint: Shortness of breath and leg swelling

priorities: Support oxygenation and reduce work of breathing
interventions: Position upright; apply oxygen per protocol
Strict I&O; consider fluid restriction per orders
Prepare/anticipate diuretics and labs per provider orders; monitor UO
reassessment: Recheck SpO2/resp effort after positioning/oxygen
Monitor urine output and symptom improvement
Watch for worsening distress or hypotension
